subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Alphabetical Order
msgSnippet: For a native Hindi speaker, those t s and d s are as different as any of the consonants in English are to us. It s not a bit subtle. Remember, they are
messageBody:
For a native Hindi speaker, those t's and d's are as different as any
of the consonants in English are to us. It's not a bit subtle.
Remember, they are represented by different letters in their alphabet.
(By the way, given that there are some 6000 languages in the world,
what are the odds that two of us on this list would reply to you
nearly at the same time with the same example from the same language?)

I've never studied Chinese--I've only observed a thing or two from
listening to Chinese friends over the years. My guess is that 'l' and
'r' are not contrasted for them at all, so they have no clue where to
place their tongues for the two sounds when they begin to study
English.

Likewise, I can only understand what you are saying about Awl and On
in a theoretical sense. I'm sure I could learn it with practice, but
it would not be easy. When people say "I can't hear the difference"
between two sounds, they mean exactly what they say.

Ted


On Nov 25, 2007 2:01 PM, Paige Gabhart <pgabhart@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Ted:
>
> I'm no linguist either, and I hesitated to mention colors in my post. I
> just used that example to help illustrate my point. Obviously, color vision
> involve the cones in the retina as you wrote and is not something learned.
> However, to digress, I have read that cultures divide the visible light
> spectrum differently concerning how far a given color is considered to
> extend.
>
> It seemed to me that the placement of the lips and tongue in "Awl" vs. "On"
> was clearly different and that sound should be audible to another English
> speaker. "Awl" requires rounded lips and the tongue must be pushed farther
> forward than its position for "on." In your Chinese example, you state that
> the Chinese have difficulty distinguishing between L and R. Is it that they
> cannot hear the difference because their language doesn't require it or that
> they don't know the proper placement of the vocal apparatus in order to
> produce the the two separate sounds?
>
> Your description of the different Hindi sounds seems more subtle than what
> I was talking about. Do you think that is wrong, or is the apparent
> subtlety simply because we don't make those distinctions?
>
> Paige
>
> P.S. thanks for the interesting tidbit about brown.
>
>
>
> Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
>
>
>
> Hi Paige,
>
> I'm no linguist, but my understanding is that sounds that are not
> contrasted in the language environment in which a person spends the
> first few years of life are quite difficult to learn to distinguish
> later on. Think about native Chinese speakers who have difficulty
> distinguishing 'l' and 'r'. (Contrast between colors, on the other
> hand, is determined physiologically by the sensitivity of each of the
> three different types of cones in the retina to variations in the
> frequency of absorbed light. People who are red-green colorblind will
> be so no matter what their cultural environment. Question: why doesn't
> the color brown appear in the rainbow? Answer: the "color" brown is an
> artifact of the human visual system, created in response to other
> colors in the visual field. It is not possible to illuminate a movie
> screen in a darkened theater with just the color brown. But I
> digress...)
>
> When I learned Hindi 20 years ago (as a Peace Corps volunteer in Fiji)
> our language trainers had to teach us where to place our tongues and
> exactly how to push air through our mouths in order for us to
> approximate the 4 different 't' sounds and the 4 different 'd' sounds
> in their language. (Look for the 4 t's and 4 d's in the Hindi alphabet
> here: http://www.omniglot.com/writing/hindi.htm) If we got these
> sounds wrong, we inadvertently spoke either nonsense or unintended
> words, always a source of hilarity. It took many months before we
> could consistently hear the differences between these sets of
> phonemes.
>
> These same trainers laughed at my friend Doug's name, because they
> couldn't distinguish it from 'dog'. They advised him to adopt another
> name so no one would laugh at him. When we asked how on Earth people
> who could hear the differences between 4 nearly identical t's and 4
> nearly identical d's could not hear the difference between 'dog' and
> 'Doug' they just smiled and shrugged.
>
> I'll have a few things to say about the Fijian language soon as well
> (in reference to QS letter #21)...
>
> Ted
>
> On Nov 25, 2007 11:59 AM, Paige Gabhart <pgabhart@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > I have been on vacation and am trying to catch up with what's been going
> > on.
> >
> > I agree with Moira. I use all three sounds: Awl, Ah and On. In fact, I
> > really don't understand what some people mean when they say they can't
> hear
> > the difference between Awl and On. It strikes me in a similar way as if
> > they said they can't distinguish between blue and green. Obviously, the
> > boundary between the two colors is somewhat ambiguous, but most of us
> have a
> > clear enough idea of what blue is versus what green is.
> >
> > I have thought that those who say they can't hear the difference actually
> > just means they don't use the Awl sound, i.e. they pronounce words such
> as
> > "all" with the On sound. I expect that they can hear the difference if
> they
> > listen closely to someone pronouncing Awl versus On even if it is not a
> > distinction they make in their own speech.
> >
> > This whole thread seems to have started as a method to enable a
> dictionary
> > to have all spelling variants placed together alphabetically. Rather than
> > throwing out a phoneme that many of us feel quite strongly about, it
> makes
> > more sense to me that if there is a variant spelling that will not be
> next
> > to the others simply put in a note directing the reader to the other
> > spelling as in: "see also: _______."
> >
> > I also feel strongly about the continued availability of "Wh". I am sure
> > that those who don't use it don't miss it, but I can assure you reading
> the
> > QS news with nary a "wh" to be seen is noticed by me every time I come
> > across a word where I would use it. I actually seem more aware of its
> > absence in writing than I am in hearing others who don't use "wh" in
> their
> > speech.
> >
> > Paige
> >
> >
> > Moira O'Brien wrote:
> >
> >
> >
> > As a speaker of RP, I can't agree to the merger of Awl Ah and On. My
> > pronunciation makes full use of all three as distinct sounds.
> > It also does with Wool & Ooze but losing one of those two would not be
> much
> > of a hardship.
> > The distinction between those sounds is quite small and not significant
> and
> > is very much like the different sounds of Schwa.
> >
> > Moira
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
>
>
>
>
